field_reports.summary: AFG: Population Movement - 03-2025 - Afghanistan Population Movement
field_reports.description:
The recent deadline imposed to expel approximately 4 million Afghan nationals by end of 2025 has significantly deteriorated the humanitarian landscape, primarily along the formal border crossing points in Torkham and Spin Boldak (Nangarhar and Kandahar provinces). The initially imposed deadline, which ended on March 31 2024, has forced many families to return to Afghanistan, resulting in a considerable influx of returnees, with a spike on April 5 2025. The situation at the Torkham and Spin Boldak borders reflects a pressing humanitarian crisis, with thousands of families returning under already challenged circumstances. The need for comprehensive support systems, including emergency health services, food security, and emergency shelter, is paramount to ensure the safety and well-being of returnees and maintain a dignified process. Immediate response interventions are required to address the needs of people crossing and to facilitate a smoother re-integration process for Afghans returning.
Between April 1 and April 6, 2025, a total of 247 families, comprising 1,307 individuals, returned to Afghanistan the formal Torkham border crossing point. The daily breakdown is as follows:

3
• April 2: 39 families (223 individuals)
• April 3: 78 families (418 individuals)
• April 4: 43 families (232 individuals)
• April 5: 87 families (434 individuals)
This surge in influx of returnees highlights the urgency of the situation, as families are compelled to leave due to the expiration of their stay in Pakistan.
Furthermore, the conditions faced by returnees at the Torkham border are dire. While the current Afghan authorities provide some financial assistance, 2,000 Afghani per person for families with fewer than five (5) members and a flat rate of 10,000 Afghani for larger families—this support is insufficient given the challenges encountered.

field_reports.summary: AFG: Population Movement - 01-2025 - Population Movement from Iran
field_reports.description:
Since January 2025, a total of 446,474 Afghan nationals have returned from Iran through the border crossings of Islam Qala and Malik, driven primarily by Iranian deportation policies and escalating conflict clashes in Iran. This surge in returnees includes many families, particularly women and children, who face harsh conditions upon arrival, such as lack of food, shelter, and medical care. On average, approximately 1,350 families, or around 9,450 individuals, are returning each day, highlighting the urgent need for humanitarian assistance and support to facilitate their reintegration into Afghan society.

Iran’s tightened regulations on residency and essential services for Afghans and the deteriorating security situation in Iran due to the conflict between Israel and Iran have prompted a huge surge in returns. These developments have spurred a second significant wave of cross-border movement, further straining Afghanistan’s already fragile infrastructure

field_reports.description:
Heavy rainfall in central Afghanistan has caused a new wave of flash floods on the 17 May 2024. This is while the country still reeling from last week's devastating floods. The newly affected provinces are Ghor, Faryad, Sar-e Pul, Samangan, Balkh and Badghis. 

According to authorities, many houses have been destroyed or damaged, large swathes of farmland were swept away, thousands of livestock killed, hundreds of bridges and culverts destroyed and thousands of trees were swept away.

field_reports.description:
Afghanistan has been experiencing persistent rainfall on the heels of an uncharacteristically dry and late winter, resulting in floods across 20 provinces: Badghis, Balkh, Daikundi, Farah, Ghor, Helmand, Herat, Kabul, Kandahar, Kapisa, Khost, Kunar, Logar, Laghman, Nangarhar, Nuristan, Parwan, Panjshir, Samangan, and Urozgan. Intense rainfall activity commenced during the week of April 16th culminating on 18th and was potentially associated with the event which impacted neighboring Pakistan, India and as far as Dubai in the United Arab Emirates, which experienced its heaviest rainfall since records began. The heavy rains resulted in another deleterious blow to the agricultural sector, with losses to over 5,428 livestock and over 84,069 acres of land. Further, the heavy rains which resulted in significant flooding is blamed for the loss of 41 lives, 84 injuries, and upwards of 8,273 houses being partially or completely damaged. Assessments continue to determine the full impact of the severe weather event with more rain in the forecast over the coming days.

The rains coincide with a weakening El Nino which is characterized by less precipitation and droughts – an experience which is not in the distant past for Afghanistan. In addition to the injuries and casualties reported, there were also damage and destruction to critical civilian infrastructure such as roads, bridges and culverts causing disruption to transportation networks.

It is anticipated that there will be a great need for urgent humanitarian assistance as the coping capacities of households are already stretched, as they face a compounding reality at a time when their recovery from previous events have been disrupted. The greatest needs will be in the areas of Shelter, Cash, food, Wash assistance and other non-food items (NFIs). With more rains in the forecast, additional flooding in low-lying and flood prone areas remain an existential threat. Additionally, urban flooding is also possible as natural waterways are blocked, and there are inadequate and limited drains. Sites downstream from large reservoirs or rivers are also particularly prone to flash flooding after relatively short periods of intense rainfall.

Heavy snowfall, rainfall and low temperatures has affected most of Afghanistan resulting in casualties and widespread disruption to services, blocked roads and significant loss of livestock of livestock between February 26 - March 1. The provinces most affected are: Badghis, Badakhshan, Faryab, Jawzjan, Kandahar, Helmand and Sari Pul. 

The government has responded to the situation wrought on by the extreme weather events with the establishment of committees to respond to the needs of the population.

field_reports.summary: AFG: Landslide - 02-2024 - Afghanistan – Landslide Noorgram district Nuristan Province
field_reports.description:
A landslide triggered by heavy snowfall and rain occurred in the village of Teten, in Noorgram district (Nuristan Province) on February 18, resulting in casualties and damage.

250 to 300 families that are living in the affected area are also at risk, and based on the report, the government decided to shift them to a safe place. More updates will come on this.

The governor of Nuristan province also requested support and immediate intervention from all humanitarian organizations on the ground.  According to ARCS assessment report, at least 25 people died, eight were injured and  More than 40 houses were fully and partially damaged

field_reports.description:
On 11.1.2024, a powerful earthquake measuring 6.4 on the Richter scale struck northeastern Afghanistan at 13:50 PM, affecting the provinces of Badakhshan and causing tremors in neighboring Pakistan. This report highlights the actions taken by the (IFRC) and the Afghanistan Red Crescent Society (ARCS) Branch Disaster Response Teams (BDRT) during the initial assessment phase.

The earthquake's epicenter was located in Jurm district in the province of Badakhshan, situated in the mountainous Hindu Kush region. The seismic event caused significant shaking, impacting buildings in Kabul, the capital city of Afghanistan, as well as Islamabad in Pakistan. Fortunately, no casualties have been reported thus far.

IFRC and ARCS Response:

In response to the earthquake, ARCS swiftly mobilized their BDRT teams to the affected areas supported by IFRC team members whom were already in the province distributing relief aid as part of the winterization assistance to the affected communities from the previous floods. The BDRT members and volunteers from ARCS are currently in the epicenter areas conducting the initial assessment. The primary objective of this assessment is to gather essential information about the impact of the earthquake, identify immediate needs, and develop an appropriate response plan.

 

Actions Taken:

The IFRC and ARCS BDRT teams have undertaken the following actions during the initial assessment:

1.       Activation of the Emergency operations center at Kabul level to ensure monitoring of the situation and ensuring coordinated approach with the movement partners as well as local authorities.

2.       Rapid Deployment: BDRT staff and volunteers were promptly deployed to the affected areas, ensuring a rapid response to the emergency. This should allow timely collection of critical information and needs assessment.

2. Needs Assessment:

IFRC and ARCS teams are currently interacting with the affected communities to ascertain their immediate needs. This includes assessing the situation and identifying requirements for emergency shelter, food, clean water, medical assistance, and other necessary relief items if needed. The assessment aims to ensure that the response efforts and plans align with the specific needs of the affected population.

3. Coordination with Local Authorities:

The ARCS are closely collaborating with local authorities, including government agencies, to ensure a coordinated assessment. This approach should ensure consistency of  of information, resources, and efficient delivery of assistance to the affected communities. Working together with local authorities enhances the effectiveness of the response effort.

field_reports.summary: AFG: Population Movement - 11-2023 - Afghanistan Population Movement
field_reports.description:
A dramatic surge in the number of people returning to Afghanistan from Pakistan since Pakistan’s announcement that all undocumented Afghans must vacate the country by 1 November or risk deportation. The daily number of arrivals, which now ranges between 9,000 and 10,000 individuals, marks a stark contrast to the previous average of approximately 300 individuals a day before the announcement on 15 September 2023. As many as 1.7 million people could be affected. 

The conditions in which they arrive in Afghanistan are dire, with many having endured arduous journeys spanning several days, exposed to the elements, and often forced to part with their possessions in exchange for transportation. 

Many of the humanitarian teams stationed in the areas where people are returning from Pakistan have reported chaotic and desperate scenes among those who have returned. 

Over 29 million Afghans inside the country are currently in need of humanitarian assistance according to UN estimates, with 17.2 million people, 40 percent of the population, struggling to meet their basic food needs. IFRC has wider Humanitarian Crises Operation across 34 provinces of the country. As of 5 November, the Emergency Appeal is 36.5 percent funded.  

The crossing points are Torkham in Nangarhar and Spin Boldak in Kandahar reception, and it will be a prospect that provinces are listed below as cross points which means that some returnees will cross the border from this point as well. Torkham and Spin Boldak areas were facing pressure due to the increasing number of returnees, resulting in longer waiting times. 

People are entering the country through the  

Badakhshan 

2. Kunar  

3. Jalalabad  

4. Khust 

5. Paktiya  

6. Paktika 

7. Zabul 

8. Kandahar 

9. Helmand  

10 Nimroorz 

11 Herat

12 Farah

13 Nooristan

field_reports.description:
Multiple earthquakes struck western Afghanistan on Saturday between 11am-12 local time, with the first and largest at a magnitude of 6.3, according to U.S. Geological Survey (USGS). Some humanitarian impacted is expected. NS collecting information, according to initial unverified information from ARCS there are five deaths and 30 injuries around Zinda Jan.

 The earthquake’s epicentre was in Zinda Jan, 40 km northwest of Herat. Prior to the Taliban take-over, the area was a no-go zone due to security issues. As of now, no official reports of casualties. However, some structural damages to houses and buildings have been observed in certain areas

In Herat City, hundreds of people left their homes and workplaces, and headed to the streets.

According to preliminary information from ARCS, there are five deaths and 100 injuries around Zinda Jan, but this is yet to be verified with the authorities. ARCS has activated their emergency operations centre to monitor and closely coordinate the response . IFRC is coordinating with PNS in the country as well as with ANDMA , the national disaster management agency 

 

We can expect casualties, damages, and some humanitarian impact in areas closer to the epicentre. The areas are sparsely populated.

field_reports.summary: AFG: Kunar, Nangarhar and laghman Earthquake(14 Sep 2022)
field_reports.description: A 5.3 magnitude earthquake on the Richter scale struck the eastern region of Afghanistan on 04 September 2022, causing widespread destruction, disruption to services, and loss of life, to an already highly vulnerable population in Kunar and Nangarhar provinces. The epicenter of the earthquake is 38 km northeast of Jalalabad city, capital of neighboring Nangarhar province. The quake was felt over a wide area, including Kabul, and caused economic losses and according to the Kunar Information and Culture Director, the number of human casualties could rise.  Reports  indicate at least 10 people lost their lives and 61 others injured. Mazar Dara area of Norgal district Districts in Kunar province endured the most impact.  A rapid initial assessment conducted by ARCS reveals more than 3,000 houses were severely damaged and they have lost food and non-food items and many people were displaced from Noorgal district.  Detail multisectoral assessment to determine the exact level of damage is underway, but initial reports show the earthquake also caused damage to health facilities, education facilities, and water services.  Support for repairs and rebuilding needs to be fast-tracked because winter is on the way.  Afghanistan is still recovering from a massive earthquake that killed more than 1,000 people and more than 3,000 others injured in the eastern Paktika and neighboring Khost provinces in June 2022

According to the Pacific Disaster Center (PDC) report, an earthquake of magnitude 4.8 (also reported as 5.1M or 5.3M in other sources) hit the Kundar province in the north-eastern part of Afghanistan on Sunday 4 September 2022 in the early morning.

According to ARCS primary incident report, the district of Noorgal was particularly affected, including the villages of Mazar dara, Ghazi Abad, Jabagi, Wadir, Gurbaz, Sahil Tangi, Sinzai, Shorang shaal, Masood, Shamash Areet and oshlet. According to the first reports available, 9 people were killed and 25 others were injured.

160 families were displaced due to the earthquake in Dajba village, and the primary information indicate that 600 houses have been destroyed as well as property damaged, according to the Afghan emergency teams who have visited the area.

Accrording to Latest updates from Field around 3000 Families displaced. 

In Souki district (Dewa village) and Khas kunar district, two people were injured and some houses were damaged.

In Nangarhar Province (neighbouring Kundar Province), 31 students were injured and are currently undergo treatment in a hospital.

The epicenter of the earthquake is 38 km northeast of Jalalabad city, capital of neighboring Nangarhar province. The quake was felt over a wide area, including Kabul, and caused economic losses and according to the Kunar Information and Culture Director, the number of human casualties could rise. Reports from ASADABAD indicate at least 6 people lost their lives and 9 others injured. Mazar Dara area of Norgal district Districts in Kunar province endured the most impact. A rapid initial assessment conducted by ARCS reveals more than 3,000 houses were severely damaged and they have lost food and non-food items and many people were displaced from Noorgal district. Detail multisectoral assessment to determine the exact level of damage is underway, but initial reports show the earthquake also caused damage to health facilities, education facilities, and water services. Support for repairs and rebuilding needs to be fast-tracked because winter is on the way. Afghanistan is still recovering from a massive earthquake that killed more than 1,000 people and more than 3,000 others injured in the eastern Paktika and neighboring Khost provinces in June 2022.

field_reports.description: Off-seasonal rainfall peaked between July and August 2022 in Afghanistan, causing the country's rivers to overflow. The flood affected 16 provinces, out of which 13 provinces (Ghazni, Kandahar, Kunar, Logar, Laghman, Maidan, Nangarhar, Nuristan, Paktia, Parwan, Wardak, Urozgan, and Zabul) were severely affected. A total of 156 people lost their lives and 124 people were injured, including women and children due to the floods. Over 35,700 houses were affected (16,000 houses destroyed and 19,700 partially damaged) which affected 249,900 people in the area. Thousands of acres of crops in farming fields were destroyed. The rapid assessment conducted by the Afghan Red Crescent Society (ARCS) revealed that the flash floods caused massive damage and destruction in these parts of the country. A substantial number of houses were flooded, with household items damaged. Several plots of farmland were swept away, and the flow of water cratered several roads. Many communities were left with inaccessible roads due to landslides. Because of the remoteness of some of the affected areas, the onset of harsh winters would aggravate the already precarious situation of the affected population.

Heavy off-season rains in early July caused widespread flash flooding in several regions of Afghanistan. Recently, following heavy rainfall on 15 August 2022, ten provinces, namely Parwan, Nangarhar, Paktia, Logar, Konar, Khost, Kapisa, Panjsher, Ghazni, and Baghlan reported incidents of flooding. Numerous homes and hundreds of acres of farming fields have reportedly been damaged and destroyed. The detailed assessment with coordinated efforts by relief agencies including ARCS to ascertain the extent of the damage is underway. The initial assessments by ARCS through its provincial branches in affected provinces for this recent floods indicate that 40 people have died, 54 injured, and over 100 missing. Also, 683 houses have been reported damaged, with further 733 houses partially destroyed. The scale of this disaster calls for an immediate major relief response from the government and other agencies.

It is anticipated that the coping capacities of affected households are stretched considering this is the second time in 2022 they have experienced flooding, added to the multiple crises that have been impacting Afghanistan since 2021, including a severe drought. The additional impact of flooding implies that vulnerabilities continue to increase as the capacity to cope decreases.

The Afghanistan Meteorological Department has issued warnings for heavy rain for several northern and eastern provinces, predicting a possible 40mm of rain in some areas. Neighboring parts of Pakistan’s Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province recorded over 200 mm of rain in 24 hours to 14 August 2022. More heavy rain of up to 50 mm in 24 hours is forecasted for several eastern and northern provinces including Nuristan, Kunar, Laghman, Nangarhar, Paktia, Paktika, Ghazni, and Zabul until at least the end of August. The most pressing problem facing the humanitarian effort is access to the affected populations and areas, with roads currently reported to be closed. The continuous flooding in these locations, coupled with the fact that the last quarter of the year will be winter, calls for urgent efforts to address immediate humanitarian needs.

Over 35,700 houses were affected (16,000 houses destroyed and 19,700 partially damaged) which affected 249,900 people in the area. Thousands of acres of crops in farming fields were destroyed. The rapid assessment conducted by the Afghan Red Crescent Society (ARCS) revealed that the flash floods caused massive damage and destruction in these parts of the country. A substantial number of houses were flooded, with household items damaged. Several plots of farmland were swept away, and the flow of water cratered several roads. Many communities were left with inaccessible roads due to landslides. Because of the remoteness of some of the affected areas, the onset of harsh winters would aggravate the already precarious situation of the affected population.
results.name: Afghanistan - Flash Floods (July 2022)

results.summary:
The evolving situation in Afghanistan is increasingly creating new potential drivers and triggers for cross-border displacement. The 2021 Afghanistan Humanitarian Needs Overview identified 18.4 million people in need of humanitarian assistance with 6.3 million being in extreme or catastrophic severity of needs; this figure is now likely to have increased due to the recent events in country. The situation remains uncertain in Afghanistan and may evolve rapidly.

Afghanistan faces an alarming humanitarian emergency and a worsening economic crisis, both likely to be further compounded by the approaching winter season. Almost half the population faces colossal humanitarian needs wrought by a combination of crises: displacement, devastation of COVID-19 pandemic, drought, acute food shortages, a fractured health system, poor access to services, and restrictive social norms. More than 558,000 Afghans have been internally displaced by the conflict since January 2021, 80 per cent of these newly internally displaced are women and children.

According to the drought declaration by the Afghanistan government of 22 June 2021, the country’s wheat crop will be reduced by nearly two million tons, and more than three million livestock are in danger of perishing due to a lack of fodder and water. IPC new projections for the period June – November 2021 estimates that, 2,742,741 Afghans are likely to be classified in Phase 4 (catastrophic) in terms of Food Insecurity and 6,719,607 in Phase 3 (emergency). The compounding impacts of drought and conflict which escalated in July and the first half of August have exacerbated the hard living conditions in a country that is also grappling with COVID-19 and poverty. Access to banking services has been severely constrained, with cashflow crippled. Collapse of Afghanistan’s economy would result in catastrophic consequences for vulnerable Afghans, including potentially fueling cross-border movements for economic reasons.

Therefore, based on analysis of the ongoing social, economic, political and security situation in Afghanistan, it is assessed that a further political and humanitarian deterioration in the country is likely to result in new population movements to neighbouring countries. A potential worst-case scenario – utilized by the UNHCR and inter-agency partners - envisages the arrival of an additional 515,000 Afghan refugees into neighbouring countries before the end of 2021.

Any major population movement will require an immediate and sustained humanitarian intervention in neighbouring countries. This will include critical life-saving humanitarian assistance at border points and in designated sites in coordination with respective authorities.

There are up to six million Afghans living outside of Afghanistan – in Europe, Asia Pacific and the Middle East - following several decades of instability in the country. New arrivals in 2021 will join more than 2.2 million registered refugees who have fled previous waves of insecurity, instability and violence to neighbouring countries. There are a further 3 million Afghans with varying status including many irregular migrants, who have been hosted in the Islamic Republic of Iran and the Islamic Republic of Pakistan over the past four decades. It will be important to maintain humanitarian assistance and protection for both new arrivals, and those previously displaced, as well as host communities.

Beyond the scope of this Emergency Appeal, there may also be onward movements and humanitarian needs in secondary countries, with Afghans taking routes to Turkey, Greece and the Western Balkans region. It will be critical to both monitor these trends and developments, as well as to be prepared and ready to provide increased principled humanitarian assistance and protection along existing migratory routes to those on the move– irrespective of their status – and to host communities in secondary countries.
results.name: Regional Population Movement - Afghanistan | Preparedness and Response

results.summary: In late night of 28 July 2021 (Wednesday), massive flash floods, triggered by heavy rain, occurred in Mirdesh village in Kamdesh district in Nuristan province – eastern part of Afghanistan. As per the initial field reports, around 150 lives are lost with 113 dead bodies found as of 31 July 2021 – others were still missing. Around 300 residential houses are impacted with 200 houses fully damaged. One public bridge and four small bridges are also damaged. The water also swept away cattle, destroyed agricultural lands and also demolished a large part of a road in Kamdesh district.

A  total  of 16  provinces  in  five  regions  across  the  country  were  affected  by  consecutive  flash  floods on  3May2021 following heavy rainssince2 May2021. According to initial reports obtained from Afghan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA)and other sources, the death toll has reached to 61 persons while 33 persons sustained injuries. The flood also impacted roads, sub-roads, irrigation system and 100 acres of agriculture land in 16 provinces.

Samangan  and  Herat  provinces  were  the  worst  affected  by  devastating  floods.  Provincial  Disaster  Management Committees  (PDMC)  and  OCT  meetings  convened  to  coordinate  assessment  and  response.  Per  the  initial  reports, approx. 4,400 families were affected currently being assessed by joint teams.

results.summary:
Afghanistan is still facing one of the worst humanitarian crises in the world resulting from compounded impacts of multiple shocks. The combination of disasters caused by natural hazards – including severe drought, flooding and earthquakes – public health emergencies, and economic hardship have increased humanitarian needs exponentially. The political changes of August 2021 prompted the application of a sanctions regime which has fueled economic hardship due to constrained international banking. According to the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), 28.3 million people will require multi-sectoral humanitarian assistance in 2023 as the country enters its third consecutive year of drought-like conditions and the second year of crippling economic decline. This reflects a 16 per cent increase from the 24.4 million people who required humanitarian assistance in 2022 and a 54 per cent increase from the 18.4 million people who required humanitarian assistance in 2021.

Key drivers of humanitarian need in 2023 are multidimensional: a protracted drought, climate-induced disasters, other hazards, protection concerns particularly for women and girls, economic hardship, and constrained access to essential services. Furthermore, while there is no more widespread conflict, the effects of a 40-year conflict and situations of violence continue to slow the move towards recovery and building resilience. There are needs in every province of the country, with extreme need in 33 out of 34 provinces and 27 out of 34 major cities/provincial capitals with the rest in severe need, indicating how widespread the crisis is across the country. Even with two-thirds of the country already having humanitarian needs in 2023, further deterioration is highly possible unless the root causes and drivers of need are addressed. Substantial investments in water infrastructure, sustainable agriculture, alternative livelihoods, gender policy reform and macroeconomic stabilization are urgently needed, along with the stabilization of services supporting basic human needs – especially health care and social services – to reduce dependence on humanitarian actors to provide emergency care and transition to longer-term support.
results.name: Afghanistan: Humanitarian Crises
